awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research : The Influence of Mangrove Invasion and Rising Temperatures on Belowground Processes in  Coastal Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
The marshes and mangroves that line our coasts protect human populations from large storms and provide recreational activities for millions of people. The very existence of these coastal ecosystems depends on their ability to gain soil to keep pace with rising seas. Wetland plant root growth pushes the soil surface upward relative to the ocean, but not all plants do this in the same way. Large areas of southeastern US coastal wetlands have converted from grassy marshes to woody mangrove forests as temperatures have increased over the past decades, possibly enhancing the capacity of these ecosystems to resist storms and build soil.  Using experiments that simulate future ecosystems, the team of scientists will investigate how Florida wetlands, both marshes and mangroves, will continue to protect people as both temperatures and seas continue to rise. They will use their results to perform an economic assessment of these changing coastal ecosystems at three Florida reserves used heavily by the public. In addition to advancing understanding of coastal ecosystem responses to varying climate, results from their assessment will be used to 1) inform federal, state and local land managers about the changing coastal protection value of their lands and 2) educate visitors about these special coastal landscapes.

Mangrove invasion could change the nature of root inputs and potentially alter soil elevation. Warming could also accelerate microbial decomposition of organic matter and thus decrease or reverse soil accumulation, which could put wetlands at risk in the face of rising seas. The research team will address the question: How do warming and mangrove invasion into salt marshes alter root productivity and organic matter decomposition, mechanisms that control coastal wetland viability? Using six existing research sites along the East Coast of FL, passive warming chambers and mesocosm experiments, the investigators propose to examine the countervailing influences of rising temperatures and plant invasion on soil elevation gain. The team will conduct warming experiments at each of three FL coastal wetland sites, which will be some of the first warming experiments in tropical and subtropical climates, thus filling a major gap in scientific knowledge. In order to assess how a variable climate and mangrove invasion will alter the coastal protection capacity of FL wetland ecosystems, the investigators will perform a natural capital assessment at these sites using the InVEST software developed by the Natural Capital Project. They will use this ecosystem service assessment to develop a 3D video informing visitors to these reserves of how their public lands are changing.

por.por_cntn:
Wetland plant communities play a vital role in the functioning of healthy coastal ecosystems which provide many services to society, ranging from habitat and fisheries support to storm surge protection and recreation. Many questions remain regarding how coastal salt marshes may respond to rapidly changing environmental conditions, particularly atmospheric warming and sea-level rise. In North America, atmospheric warming is resulting in a poleward (northward) expansion of black mangrove (Avicennia germinans), a subtropical coastal wetland tree, into temperate salt marsh dominated by smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora). Although multiple studies have investigated the effects of atmospheric warming on mangrove range expansion into salt marsh, little is known regarding how warmer water temperatures in estuarine ecosystems and resultant chronic warming of wetland soils will alter belowground processes, above- and belowground plant productivity, species interactions, and plant community composition, particularly in ecotones where black mangrove is expanding into smooth cordgrass marsh.

To address these uncertainties, a controlled, one-year tidal mesocosm experiment was established in a temperature-controlled greenhouse and three estuarine water temperature treatments were simulated. This mesocosm experiment was a key part of a research collaborative with Villanova University in which they deployed experimental warming chambers in the smooth cordgrass/mangrove marshes at Guana Tolomato Mantanzas National Estuarine Research Reserve (GTMNERR), Florida, USA that were designed to primarily warm the aboveground portions of the plants, whereas the mesocosm experiment was complementary to the field study and designed to warm the intertidal waters and soil under controlled greenhouse conditions.

The three estuarine water temperature treatments that were simulated in the tidal mesocosm were: 1) ambient annual estuarine water temperature of 24 ℃ based on data near GTMNERR and the current northern latitudinal limit of black mangrove in N. America, 2) a moderate water temperature treatment of 4 ℃ above ambient (28 ℃) , and 3) a high water temperature treatment of 8 ℃ above ambient (32 ℃). Transplants of black mangrove and smooth cordgrass from GTMNERR were transplanted into the mesocosm to establish four vegetation conditions: 1) black mangrove grown separately in monoculture, 2) smooth cordgrass grown separately in monoculture, 3) black mangrove and smooth cordgrass grown together in mixture, and 4) unvegetated wetland soil.

 Biomass results revealed that both black mangrove and smooth cordgrass displayed increased productivity under moderate soil warming. However, the productivity of black mangrove then decreased under high soil warming while the productivity of smooth cordgrass continued to increase under high soil warming. Another key finding is that although both black mangrove and smooth cordgrass were more productive when grown separately in monoculture than when grown together in mixture, the overall productivity of the mixture community was not decreased as the two species interacted. This indicates that as black mangrove expands into salt marsh dominated by smooth cordgrass, the plant community composition shifts, but the overall productivity of the salt marsh is unchanged, at least during the initial years following mangrove encroachment. Soil organic matter accumulation can play an important role in influencing the ability of a marsh platform to build and keep pace with sea-level rise. Decomposition rates in this study were significantly greater under moderate soil warming in all the vegetation treatments except black mangrove grown in monoculture which did not display a significant effect of soil temperature on decomposition, illustrating the complexity of these ecosystems.

Overall, this mesocosm study has advanced scientific understanding and provided novel insights in a complementary and controlled manner to the collaborative field efforts on the effects of belowground warming on above- and belowground production and biomass allocation dynamics of two key wetland plant species at the species and community level. This collaborative project has improved our understanding of how coastal ecosystems may be altered in the future as temperatures and sea levels continue to rise. These findings are of value not only to scientists, but to society as a whole since humans are an integral and dynamic component of these complex ecosystems and the services they provide.
